abstract.t: The IETF has consensus that pervasive monitoring is an attack that should be mitigated via the design of protocols, where possible.

section.title: It's an Attack
section.t: The technical plenary of IETF 88 discussed pervasive monitoring and participants strongly agreed that this was an attack and one that should be mitigated where possible via the design of protocols that make pervasive monitoring significantly more expensive or infeasible. This Best Current Practice (BCP) documents that consensus.

For the purposes of this BCP pervasive monitoring is the widespread privacy-invasive gathering of protocol artefacts including application content, protocol meta-data (such as headers) or keys used to secure protocols. Other forms of traffic analysis, for example, timing or measuring packet sizes can also be used for pervasive monitoring. A full problem statement with more examples and description can be found in . Note that more limited-scope monitoring to assist with network management or that is REQUIRED in order to operate the network or an application are not considered pervasive monitoring. There is though a clear potential for network management mechanisms to be abused as part of pervasive monitoring, so this tension needs careful consideration in protocol design.

The motivation behind pervasive monitoring is not particularly relevant for this document, but can include non-targetted nation-state surveillance. Equally, one can envisage non-nation-state actors using similar techniques for criminal or legal but privacy-unfriendly purposes.

There are various ways in which IETF protocols can be designed in order to mitigate pervasive monitoring, but those will change over time as mitigation and attack techniques develop and so are not described here. This BCP simply records the consensus to design protocols so as to mitigate the attack.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This BCP is all about privacy. More information about the relationship between security and privacy threats can be found in . Section 5.1.1 of specifically addresses surveillance as a combined security-privacy threat.
